qas.question: London is second only to what city in terms of its foreign population?
What percentage of London residents are foreign-born?
Many German-born Londoners were British citizens by birth due to what?

answers.text: parents serving in the British Armed Forces in Germany

qas.question: When did London see its highest population numbers?

answers.text: 1939 immediately before the outbreak of the Second World War

qas.question: What was London's estimated population at the time of the 2011 census?

context: The 2011 census recorded that 2,998,264 people or <a1_0>36.7%<a1_0/> of London's population are foreign-born making London the city with the second largest immigrant population, behind <a0_0>New York City<a0_0/>, in terms of absolute numbers. The table to the right shows the most common countries of birth of London residents. Note that some of the German-born population, in 18th position, are British citizens from birth born to <a2_0>parents serving in the British Armed Forces in Germany<a2_0/>. With increasing industrialisation, London's population grew rapidly throughout the 19th and early 20th centuries, and it was for some time in the late 19th and early 20th centuries the most populous city in the world. Its population peaked at 8,615,245 in <a3_0>1939 immediately before the outbreak of the Second World War<a3_0/>, but had declined to 7,192,091 at the 2001 Census. However, the population then grew by just over a million between the 2001 and 2011 Censuses, to reach <a4_0>8,173,941<a4_0/> in the latter enumeration.
